title: Monday, 9th October, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM11:00am

Morning

PM11:01am

So Richard H Thaler gets the Nobel for economics

PM11:01am

And loads of people on Twitter go "oh, that's boring"

11:01 am
PM11:02am

Poor chap

PM11:02am

We can at least share his pic here

PM11:02am

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Behavioural econonomist

PM11:02am

https://en.wikiped...iki/Richard_Thaler

PM11:03am

You can follow him here https://twitter.com/R_Thaler

11:03 am
undefined
PM11:04am

That's actually one of the most exciting things that's happened this morning

PM11:04am

Well, there's the Turkish lira crash

11:04 am
PM11:04am

But that's not really our bag

PM11:04am

Corporate news v v light

PM11:04am

Which has become the norm on Mondays

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Not sure why that is

PM11:05am

Is it cos the Sunday business press has gone cold?

PM11:05am

Or Sunday press reduced to re-heats

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Like John Flint becoming the new ceo at HSBC

PM11:05am

Well, the Sunday Times has confirmed that news

PM11:06am

But it was known, right?

11:06 am
HSBC Holdings PLC (HSBA:LSE): Last: 756.00, down 0.9 (-0.12%), High: 757.20, Low: 753.90, Volume: 3.39m
BE11:06am

..... I don't really keep track of the appointments pages. Perhaps, dunno.

PM11:06am

https://www.ft.com...-b797-b61809486fe2

11:07 am
PM11:07am

Oh, and more on Thaler here btw: https://www.ft.com...-5bbd-af33dc531acb

undefined
BE11:08am

So ...... in terms of corporate, there's M&C.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Which is a bit of a forgotten stock generally, because there's no free float.

Millennium & Copthorne Hotels PLC (MLC:LSE): Last: 552.20, up 97.2 (+21.36%), High: 561.00, Low: 546.00, Volume: 352.16k
PM11:09am

Yeah, I'd for got it even existed

11:08 am
BE11:09am

............ and soon there's going to be even less, because the Singapore lot are doing a take private.

BE11:09am

City Developments. They own 65%, paying 545p for the rest.

BE11:10am

Now, the problem with valuing M&C is that its property portfolio's worth loads. But the property portfolio also tends to have a hotel on it.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

So you're left with the valuation (under normal circumstances) being propped up by the pipeline, which is all franchise and margin dilutive.

BE11:13am

Which makes 552.5p look not unreasonable, and I'm a wee bit surprised to see it trading so close to terms.

BE11:13am

Here's Berenberg's pre-bid valuation works.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

BE11:13am

(To be clear, it's 545p plus a 7.5p dividend.)

PM11:13am

Ah, right

11:13 am
BE11:13am

(@Minerve: 25% is sufficient for indexing.)

BE11:16am

......... and I'm not sure if anyone else still follows. Credit Suisse, Jefferies, Stifel etc are all covering but none has bothered publishing on it for ages.

BE11:16am

Feels more of a mercy killing than a bid, though I doubt that'll stop some minority somewhere whining about the price.

11:16 am
undefined
BE11:17am

S&N mentioned, inevitably, post the CEO's retirement.

PM11:17am

Olivier Bohuon

11:17 am
Smith & Nephew PLC (SN.:LSE): Last: 1,377, down 14.78 (-1.06%), High: 1,388, Low: 1,367, Volume: 1.32m
PM11:17am

Going the end of next year

PM11:17am

https://www.invest...1710090700040016T/

11:17 am
BE11:18am

Can we read anything into that apropos of the recent noise around S&N we've not been talking about.

BE11:18am

Probably not.

PM11:18am

hmm

11:18 am
PM11:18am

That's difficult to call

PM11:18am

Not encouraging to those hotter types whispering about S&N

BE11:19am

Backtracking a moment, Olivier Bohuon joined in 2011. The standard form is for CEOs to spend seven years in the chair. He'll be 60 on his next birthday.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

And trading looks fine.

BE11:20am

I'd speculate that, if S&N were sitting on an approach from a peer, then Mr Bohuon might hold off for a few weeks.

BE11:21am

But if S&N were sitting on an approach from a peer, they'd probably have to tell us and/or the dozen other media organisations that have been pestering them over recent weeks.

11:21 am
BE11:22am

Course, if [INSERT NAME OF PEER HERE] were weighing up an offer for S&N, that's an entirely different story. And a rather trickier story to deal with, either as CEO or hack.

BE11:22am

Anyway, we have S&N results due early next month.

BE11:22am

Have Citi on those.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Citi Q3 sales expectations — We believe disrupted surgical procedures due to weather in the US, particularly Florida, may be worth around $3-6mn of headwind, or c. 40bps to organic growth in Q3. We forecast organic growth of +2.7% in Q3 with sales of $1,139mn, implying that excluding the impact of the hurricane, SN saw a c. +40bps acceleration relative to Q1 & Q2, driven by slightly softer comps and continued strength in knees. While we expect some of the lost procedures to return in Q4, we do not think the entire c. 40bps returns as hospitals are likely to run up against utilization limits.
 Minor model changes — We have updated our model for FX, with very small tweaks to divisional organic growth. Our FY17E earnings fall -10bps and FY18E increase by +30bps.

undefined
PM11:24am

Any movement in AstraZeneca?

11:24 am
AstraZeneca PLC (AZN:LSE): Last: 5,153, down 1 (-0.02%), High: 5,167, Low: 5,139, Volume: 285.46k
PM11:24am

This lung cancer news this morning carried the following headline...

PM11:24am

FDA grants Tagrisso BTD for 1st-line EGFR nsclc

11:24 am
PM11:25am

What the hell is that supposed to mean?

PM11:25am

BTD is Breakthrough Therapy Designation , of course

PM11:25am

EGFR?

11:25 am
PM11:25am

epidermal growth factor receptor

PM11:26am

nsclc?

PM11:26am

non-small cell lung cancer

11:25 am
PM11:26am

https://www.invest...1710090700040020T/

PM11:26am

Obviously all in the price already

BE11:27am

......... dunno. My impression as a non-specialist is that oncology's quite complicated. I'm not sure this is a case where we can claim they're going too native on us, given it's literally life and death stuff so deserves a certain amount of precision.

11:27 am
PM11:27am

Fair enough

BE11:28am

Incidentally, HSBC has a rather wide-ranging "drug disruption" thing out today.

BE11:28am

As in, tech getting into drug development, in theory disrupting the incumbents.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Samsung BioLogics, a subsidiary of Samsung Electronics/SDI, is rapidly becoming one of the largest contract manufacturers of biologics globally. Six years after being founded, it now has a market value of nearly USD20bn. GE Healthcare, a subsidiary of General Electric, is now one of the most prolific manufacturers of single-use biologics manufacturing facilities and it is also a leading player in downstream biologic drug purification.

BE11:29am

Samsung Bioepis, a Samsung subsidiary developing biosimilar drugs, was founded in 2012 and it already has five drugs approved in Europe and the US. Verily, a subsidiary of Alphabet/Google, has drug, diagnostic and medtech development programmes across multiple therapeutic areas. Calico, also an Alphabet/Google subsidiary, is involved in drug development, with the former Genentech CEO driving the drug discovery programmes.

BE11:29am

Medical imaging is a form of Diagnostics. The three biggest companies that make X-ray, CT and MRI scanners are GE, Siemens and Philips. Their activities are much wider than medical imaging and could move further towards traditional lab-based or point-of-care Diagnostics. Online Pharmacies in the US, run by traditional pharmacy chains and integrated with PBMs (pharmacy benefit managers), are becoming more prevalent; none is owned by large internet companies or online retail companies.

11:29 am
PM11:30am

Interesting theme

BE11:30am

....... so, keep your eye on it, says HSBC.

BE11:30am

Predicting the future: These observations are all interesting, but how do we think they will evolve? We make several predictions: 1. GE could move into biologics manufacturing, initially contract manufacturing; 2. other tech companies could move into biologics manufacturing and/or drug development, increasing the competition for existing pharmaceutical and biotech drug developers; 3. medical imaging companies evolve their businesses further towards laboratory and point-of-care diagnostics, increasing the competition for traditional diagnostic companies; 4. Samsung Bioepis/BioLogics evolves into a de novo biologics drug developer; 5. Alphabet’s biotech and medtech companies successfully develop commercial products and acquire established biotech and medtech businesses to accelerate their growth; 6. large internet retailers could acquire/move into online pharmacy provision; this would be negative for drug pricing in the US, in our view.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Though it does occur ........ if Alphabet thinks it has a knack of lobbying through regulation, wait until it tries pharma.

PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

BE11:32am

(@Mouselet: only found out quite recently about AZN's biosimilar business. Interesting theme.)

11:32 am
PM11:32am

Hey, look at this from CS Bryce...

PM11:32am

Three astonishing results over the past two weeks – all from Ocado

PM11:32am

Astonishing!

11:32 am
PM11:33am

Last week saw Ocado win our Grocer 33 benchmarking exercise for its first win since we started tracking it over a year ago; this week it proved that it was not a fluke, as won again

PM11:33am

Even using 4-week moving averages, the effects are clear, as shown in Figure 1. Of course, "winning" the pricing game is not always desirable; it may be an attempt to reset expectations or drive volume – in both cases it is expensive from a margin perspective. But even more surprising was that availability fell to 0 (out of 20) this week. It had never before been below 15, and averaged 18.8 over the past year.

PM11:33am

Ocado 'winning' the price game.

11:33 am
PM11:33am

I'd better get the chart

PM11:33am

PM11:34am

Right click, new tab

11:34 am
PM11:34am

Ocado is in green, at the top

PM11:34am

Won't that just destroy any lingering bits of profitability?

PM11:35am

Just one more par from the short Food for thought note from Credit SUisse

11:35 am
PM11:35am

Tesco keeps the spotlight on pricing. Tesco's 1H18 results this week kept the focus on relative price positioning. It said it was passing along ~1% less inflation than the market, but more importantly, that its current price level was essentially where it wanted it to be. Tesco's key benchmark is Asda, not the discounters, and we have seen the Tesco / Asda gap narrow over the past two years, so if Tesco is happy (or at least happier) with its price positioning, margin pressure within the sector may fall.

Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 295.70, down 0.3 (-0.10%), High: 297.70, Low: 294.70, Volume: 97.64k
undefined
11:35 am
BE11:36am

So, Revolution's response is on the tape.

BE11:36am

https://www.invest...1710091131370761T/

BE11:36am

And it's very long.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Though the gist of it seems to be, "look, give us cash"

BE11:37am

Just to catch up ..... This is Detic, the former Luminar, trying to pitch it's all-stock merger with Revolution and -- possibly surprisingly -- getting some support.

BE11:38am

Artemis, 12% Revolution shareholder, has sniffed blood and decided to withdraw its backing from the Stonegate bid.

11:38 am
PM11:38am

The Stonegate off is about to be voted on, no?

BE11:38am

Could be deferred, buy scheduled for October 17.

BE11:39am

As I say, new statement from Revolution is very much "show me the money" ..... which Detic has said previously might be possible.

11:39 am
Revolution Bars Group PLC (RBG:LSE): Last: 210.17, up 3.17 (+1.53%), High: 210.25, Low: 209.25, Volume: 99.40k
BE11:40am

Peel Hunt does some numbers .............

BE11:40am

At 203p/share (Stonegate’s offer price), we estimate a merged Deltic-RBG would be valued at just 4.6x EBITDA or a 15.4% equity FCF yield. A 10% equity FCF yield would equate to 314p/share for a business that comprises Deltic, which has grown EBITDA by 82% over the last four years, and RBG, which has growth EBITDA by 38% over the last four years.

11:40 am
BE11:41am

Here's that head-to-head ...........

BE11:41am

• RBG. Since 2013, RBG has grown EBITDA by 38% self-financed,
despite growing its average number of outlets by just 11%. New sites typically generate 30-40% cash returns, and over the next two years the estate is forecast to grow by 17%, driving £2m annual growth in EBITDA.
• Deltic. Since 2013, Deltic’s EBITDA has grown by 82% to £13.3m with admissions growing by 8.0% with sales rising by 26.2%. Over this period, its admissions’ share of sales has fallen to 19.3% from 21.3% with admissions spend per head (up 5.0%) being outpaced by drink spend per head rising by 19.0%, with cash returns on refurbishment running at c50%.

BE11:42am

Which seems to skip over the details of how badly things got for Luminar as was.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Still .........

BE11:42am

Deltic’s offer proposes to add £22m of EBITDA in 2019E at an EV cost of just £82m (£54m equity and £28m debt), representing an opportunity for RBG shareholders to pay just 3.7x EV/EBITDA to enlarge a growing business. The alternative is to be bought out in cash at 3.6x site-level EV/EBITDA (2019E) with the company being forced to de-list.
With such strong growth and returns, there is a case for equity offers being as attractive as cash offers, yet the board and its advisors are still recommending a 203p offer over a 314p offer. They still only have their own 4% of the shares as irrevocable acceptances, and Artemis, the largest shareholder (with 14% of the company), has withdrawn its support for the 203p offer. Like Artemis, other shareholders now have a chance to provide the board and its advisors with some advice, and we believe that advice should include aspiring to something greater than 203p/share.

BE11:43am

And Canaccord.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Artemis's decision at the end of last week to withdraw its letter of support for the Stonegate 203p/share cash offer for Revolution Bars Group paves the way for an auction that will determine the future destination of the ownership of Revolution. Deltic's offer is highly credible. If Stonegate wants to win, it needs to offer more: every extra turn of EBITDA on the valuation multiple adds c.30p to the price.

BE11:44am

At the 203p offer price from Stonegate, the trailing exit EV/EBITDA multiple (including pre-opening costs added back) is 6.4x. Assuming £7.7m of synergies (including £0.9m of financing synergy) identified by Deltic then the exit multiple drops to a measly 4.4x. Using the corrected debt forecast from Deltic then Revolution could nearly double the value of their investment from today's share price. Assuming £40m of EBITDA in FY19E, combined net debt of £35m, an enlarged share count of 75m shares and an EV/EBITDA multiple of 8.0x, this generates a share price of 392p.

Timings are dependent on events. Our understanding is as follows: Deltic has until 5 pm on Tuesday 10 October to alter its proposal (add a cash element?) and then it can do nothing until the scheduled court meeting on Tuesday 17 October. RBG is technically in control of this process and it could adjourn the date pending further developments.
Stonegate could ask for a delay if it returned with a higher cash offer for example.
Stonegate could also flip into a straightforward offer that would require 50% acceptance to be passed (Artemis could block a de-listing with a 15% stake - but Stonegate could add conditions to the offer e.g. 90% acceptance). Sit tight.

undefined
11:45 am
BE11:45am

Oh, here's a thing.

PM11:46am

Go on

BE11:46am

JP Morgan's trying to build a computer to read their analyst reports, so people don't have to.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Honestly. It is.

BE11:47am

There's a 66 page report on it from the AsiaPac quant team.

PM11:47am

Do explain

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Well, I'm not sure I can. "Machine Learning in Big Data for the Classification of News Sentiment for Equities," is the subtitle.

BE11:48am

So, the way I understand it, they fed in a load of sellside reports into a machine and .... actually, I don't understand it at all.

BE11:48am

In this report we explore a new big data set for sentiment classification using the last five years of JPM analyst reports (over 250,000 reports in total). We use the analyst’s own rating (OW, N, UW) to give us a subset of over 75,000 labelled samples for learning the difference between good and bad sentiment in financial writing. We then use our best classifier on news articles about stocks to test trades using the sentiment.

11:48 am
BE11:49am

Our trading backtests looked at news feeds with over 100,000 headlines for both long and short stock signals in several global indices (DJI, NASDAQ, HSI, ASX, MSCI UK, and MSCI APEX50). We found our signal produced around 10-20bps L/S per week (6-12% p.a.) and it worked better in smaller caps with no correlation to traditional sentiment factors derived from earnings momentum or analyst rating changes.

PM11:49am

Marshall Wace have been doing this for about 15 years

PM11:49am

Getting sell side to plug their recommendations into the MW black box

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Sort of, yes, but also no. ....... And please note, this is the first page of the executive summary. This is for general readership.

PM11:50am

ok

BE11:50am

In our training phase we start with a neural net generated document embedding model developed at Google (doc2vec) trained on JPM report abstracts. Because we focus only on analyst reports our word embeddings are more relevant to equities (the original Google model is more general purpose where for example ‘overweight’ is mapped closer to ‘obese’ but in our model it is closer to the word ‘bullish’).

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Next using just the set of rated analyst reports (i.e. OW, N, UW) we extract over 4.3 million ‘bag of word’ features from the reports and use an aggressive feature engineering pipeline to reduce this down to the most relevant 5,000. Finally we combine the features of the document embedding with the bag of words and train a classifier using the analyst’s stock ratings as the class labels.

BE11:50am

In all we test five machine learning classifiers: Deep & Shallow Neural Nets, Logistic Regression, Support Vector Machines, and Random Forests.
We also compare these with a Gaussian Naïve Bayes approach and the VADER Lexicon (which was built for micro-blog sentiment analysis and so underperforms the other classifiers).
Of these classifiers we found that Logistic Regression tended to be the most robust and easiest to use, while also benefitting more from the feature engineering. The neural nets performed the best when the features were basic, but not as the features became more sophisticated.

BE11:51am

Sixty-six pages of this.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

That look like this, mostly.

BE11:51am

PM11:51am

Blimey

11:52 am
BE11:52am

But also like this

BE11:52am

BE11:53am

And occasionally like this.

11:52 am
BE11:53am

BE11:53am

I think the conclusion is "buy equities", BTW.

undefined
11:53 am
PM11:54am

We're not going to top that in the seven mins that remain

BE11:55am

There's surely something to keep us going, tho.

BE11:55am

Citi on telcos, I guess, if we want to stick with sellside.

11:55 am
BT Group (BT.A:LSE): Last: 279.47, down 3.69 (-1.30%), High: 281.65, Low: 279.44, Volume: 7.39m
Talktalk Telecom Group PLC (TALK:LSE): Last: 216.50, up 1.2 (+0.56%), High: 216.90, Low: 205.00, Volume: 518.93k
BE11:56am

Downgrades both of those. Fibre glut is the theme. Loads of cash flooding into the sector and digging up roads.

11:56 am
BE11:57am

Our UK Fibre Builders symposium on 18 Sep showed that alternative local network operators are successfully raising capital and have bold plans for growth even if their build capacity is limited for the moment. We increase the overbuild reach that we assume for FTTP players (excl Virgin) long-term to 25% from 15% of the country, and increase the competitor uptake expected to 50%, reducing our forecast for Openreach's line count to compensate. We also raise our forecast for Openreach's capex allowing more for investment in customer connection and adding the USO.

BE11:57am

Openreach already stepping on the gas with FTTP and has some lost time to recover. Its FTTP acceleration may though take some time to negotiate, and we expect competitors and Ofcom to agree that they want alternatives to Openreach in some parts of the country, aside from Virgin Media. Ofcom will need to decide how to approach wholesale pricing, whether to allow co-investors ownership benefits and whether to encourage Openreach to enter reciprocal arrangements with other players

BE11:58am

Our forecast for BT's capex in FY19 and FY20 rises 8-9% and FCF falls 8-12% to £2.9bn and £2.7bn respectively. We assume BT loses 1.5m wholesale broadband customers (incl ULL) over the five years from March 2018 (13% of the total) as FTTP overbuilders reach wider and more effectively than we allowed for previously. Our estimate changes leave BT looking reasonably valued compared to peers rather than inexpensive, and it looks to us like the market's pricing in of capex risk has gone far enough already. We downgrade to Neutral with a 310p target price (from 360p).

11:58 am
BE11:58am

TalkTalk has rallied since early August, with Ofcom's earlier proposal to regulate BT's 40Mbps broadband, and TalkTalk’s comment that it is looking to agree a retail arrangement for its mobile offer, possible contributing factors. TalkTalk can, though, no longer count on benefiting from Ofcom's dark fibre proposal since BT has won the first round of its court challenge, and that it faces risks in a transition to full fibre due to its relative lack of balance sheet flexibility. We downgrade to Sell from Neutral on an unchanged TP of 180p.

BE11:59am

See also Credit Suisse on Talktalk last week. https://www.ft.com...-9e4f-7f5e6a7c98a2

undefined

PM11:59am

Look at the time

PM12:00pm

Thanks for getting us through Bryce

PM12:00pm

And thanks for bearing with us over on the right

12:00 pm
PM12:00pm

We'll be back tomorrow at 11am.

PM12:00pm

Well, Bryce will. I'm off line for a couple of days

PM12:01pm

Till then

12:00 pm
PM12:01pm
